sub_topic: Prove that every group of order 24 is isomorphic to either the cyclic group C24, the alternating group A5, or one of the five non-abelian groups of order 24.
message_1: Given a group of order 24, prove that it is isomorphic to either the cyclic group C24, the alternating group A5, or one of the five non-abelian groups of order 24. Additionally, determine the specific group to which it is isomorphic.

To prove that a group of order 24 is isomorphic to either the cyclic group C24, the alternating group A5, or one of the five non-abelian groups of order 24, we will use the Sylow theorems. Let G be a group of order 24. Then, the prime factorization of 24 is 2^3 * 3.

By the Sylow theorems, we know that the number of Sylow 2-subgroups (n_2) divides 3 and is congruent to 1 mod 2, so n_2 can be either 1 or 3. Similarly, the number of Sylow 3-subgroups (n_3) divides 8 and is congruent to 1 mod 3, so n_3 can be either 1 or 4.

In this case, there is a unique Sylow 2-subgroup P and a unique Sylow 3-subgroup Q, both of which are normal in G. Since P and Q have coprime orders, G is isomorphic to the direct product of P and Q, which is the cyclic group C24.

Thus, the kernel has order 4, and the image of the homomorphism has order 6. This means that G is isomorphic to a semidirect product of Q and the image, which is isomorphic to either the dihedral group D12 or the dicyclic group Q12.

Case 4: n_2 = 3 and n_3 = 4
In this case, let P be a Sylow 2-subgroup of G and Q be a Sylow 3-subgroup of G. Then, G acts on the set of left cosets of P by left multiplication, and this action induces a homomorphism from G to the symmetric group S3.
